p: Consumer practices are important as well. An increase in energy‐intensive practices, such as greater use of heating and cooling or a shift to daily showering, tends to increase emissions, but modifying these practices or adopting others, such as choosing public transportation over driving, can reduce emissions (Dietz, Gardner, Gilligan, Stern, & Vandenbergh, 2009; Ehrhardt‐Martinez & Schor, 2015; Shove, Pantzar, & Watson, 2012). Choosing green energy options, such as rooftop solar photovoltaic systems, has been shown to have a strong spatial pattern of adoption leading to the conclusion that “peer effects” can be a strong force in consumer choices. Adoption often occurs among neighboring residences, irrespective of economic class and political party (Graziano & Gillingham, 2015).
